SENT.plain: In this work we investigate subcellular localization and proteolytic cleavage of different forms of ataxin-3 (AT-3), the protein responsible for spinocerebellar ataxia type 3
Normal (AT-3Q6 and AT-3Q26) and pathological (AT-3Q72) ataxins-3, as well as two truncated forms lacking poly-Q, were studied
Full-length proteins were also expressed as C14A mutants, in order to assess whether AT-3 autoproteolytic activity was involved in its fragmentation
We found that both normal and pathological proteins localized in the cytoplasm and in the nucleus, as expected, but also in the mitochondria
Microsequencing showed that all ataxins-3 underwent the same proteolytic cleavage, removing the first 27 amino acids
Interestingly, while normal ataxins were further cleaved at a number of caspase sites, pathological AT-3 was proteolyzed to a much lesser extent
This may play a role in the pathogenesis, hampering degradation of aggregation-prone expanded AT-3
In addition, autolytic cleavage was apparently not involved in AT-3 proteolysis
